wikitext.*:
{{Unnamed}}
"'''Great beasts'''"<ref name=":0">{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.04.184}}</ref>, "'''great monsters'''"<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.06.053}}</ref>, or '''"great [[Southrons|Southron]] monsters'''"<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.08.001}}</ref>, was a vague term applied to various large [[Kelvar|animals]] used in the armies of [[Sauron]] during the [[War of the Ring]]. This term was applied several times to [[oliphaunts]] (also known as ''mûmakil'' to [[Haradrim]] and [[Gondorians]]).<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 4.04.105}}</ref><sup>,</sup><ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.04.044}}</ref> The [[Witch-king's winged steed|winged steed]] of the [[Witch-king]] was also called "the great beast" twice.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.06.016}}</ref><sup>,</sup><ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.06.019}}</ref>

==History==
Near the end of the [[Third Age]], different great beasts were used as war-beasts, steeds or beasts of burden by [[Sauron]]'s armies during the [[War of the Ring]]. Some great beasts (described as ''mûmakil)'' were sent on [[14 March]] by the [[Witch-king]] to pull huge siege-towers and great engines of war to the [[City Wall]] of [[Minas Tirith]].<ref name=":0" /> The most notable of these great beasts were ones specifically tasked with pulling the huge battering ram [[Grond]] to [[Minas Tirith]]'s [[Great Gate of Minas Tirith|Great Gate]] to destroy it.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.04.185}}</ref>

While the arrows shot from the [[swan-knights]] of [[Dol Amroth]] did little to halt Grond, occasionally some of the great beasts "would go mad and spread stamping ruin among the" many [[Orcs of Mordor|Orcs]] which guarded Grond. However the bodies of the tramped Orcs were cast aside and new Orcs replaced the fallen ones just as quickly.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.04.187}}</ref>

==Speculation==
Whether the great beasts used to pull Grond were ''mûmakil'' or a different type of unknown animals from distant lands, is impossible to say for certain as we lack a more detailed description of the creatures.

==Portrayal in adaptations==
[[File:The Lord of the Rings - The Return of the King - Great Beasts.jpg|Great beasts in ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King]]''|thumb|left|150px]]
'''2003: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King]]'':'''

:The great beasts pulling [[Grond (battering ram)|Grond]] are depicted as rhinoceros-like creatures. In the Weta Workshop [[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (extended edition)|''Return of The King'' documentary]] it is revealed they are based off of [[Wikipedia:Megacerops|Brontotherium]] in appearance.

[[Image:yurgs.jpg|frame|''Yurgs'' in [[The Lord of the Rings: The Battle for Middle-earth II|BFME2]]]]
'''2006: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Battle for Middle-earth II|The Battle for Middle-earth II]]'':'''

:In this video game the basic design of the great beasts from Peter Jackson's ''The Lord of the Rings'' is kept. However, a new idea is introduced: the creatures called "great beasts" were originally used by Dwarves in the Misty Mountains as underground draft animals (depicted as being much smaller than Sauron's beasts of burden). The Dwarves called them ''yurgs''.<ref>[http://pc.ign.com/articles/690/690364p3.html Battle for Middle-earth II - The Dwarves] at [http://pc.ign.com/ IGN], accessed 16 October 2010</ref>

'''2015: ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'':'''
:In the Mordor expansion pack, the great beasts were given the name '''Sulokil'''. They were depicted as being horned, stony-skinned beasts that were a local subspecies of [[Kine of Araw|Aurochs]]. Despite living in the "Dor Amarth" region of [[Plateau of Gorgoroth]] and being used as beasts of burden by [[Sauron]], the Sulokil were  docile unless provoked.<ref>''[https://lotro-wiki.com/wiki/Sulokil Sulokil]'' on [https://lotro-wiki.com/wiki/Main_Page lotro-wiki.com]</ref> According to [[Ingold]], their meat was "rather good when cooked and seasoned".<ref>[https://lotro-wiki.com/wiki/Quest:Welcomed_Provisions Quest:Welcomed Provisions] on [https://lotro-wiki.com/wiki/Main_Page lotro-wiki.com]</ref>

:In [[Minas Morgul]] expansion, it is revealed that in the late [[Second Age]], their ancestors, the '''Sûlokil''', wandered the Plateau of Gorgoroth, then named "Mordor Besieged".<ref>''[https://lotro-wiki.com/wiki/Sûlok Sûlok]'' on [https://lotro-wiki.com/wiki/Main_Page lotro-wiki.com]</ref> During the [[Siege of Barad-dûr]] by the [[Last Alliance of Elves and Men|Great Alliance]], the Sûlokil were hunted for food since they provided the nourishment that smaller animals did not provide.<ref>[https://lotro-wiki.com/wiki/Quest:Hunting_Sûlokil Quest:Hunting Sûlokil] on [https://lotro-wiki.com/wiki/Main_Page lotro-wiki.com]</ref>
